    data-notes: Beginning with the Holocene period, the Neolithic transition marked a shift from a foraging lifestyle in the Late Mesolithic to an agricultural way of life during the Early Neolithic. In the Fertile Crescent, one of the centers of the farming economy, crop domestication began in temperate climates with dry and hot summers ('Csa' in the Köppen Climate Classification) around 9000 BC. In its early stages (pioneer front of neolithization), crop transfer —more so than animal domestication— required areas with similar climate and seasonal patterns (e.g., Growing Degree Days, Temperature). This presentation will examine the spread of farming across the Mediterranean from ca. 9000 to 5000 BC, using quantitative methods (R neonet framework) to analyze over 4,000 curated radiocarbon dates, alongside Köppen Climate Classification past reconstructions (R pastclim package), to assess the spread of the farming economy and changes in the climates inhabited by the earliest farmers in the Mediterranean.

::: notes
- With R functions coming from the C14bazaar R package and curated with the NeoNet R series of functions, we are gathering some 10,000 radiocarbon dates coming from 8 different datasets and databases. 
- We map these dates to the Neonet periods (here on the left **class**).
- Then we remove duplicated dates and discard outliers (currently in process).
- Some 4,000 dates are now available for the study.
:::

### Methods

::: columns

::: {.column width="50%"}
<img src="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/zoometh/thomashuet/master/img/app-github.png" style="height: 90px;vertical-align: middle;"/><img src="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/EvolEcolGroup/pastclim/master/man/figures/logo.png" style="height: 110px;vertical-align: middle;"/><br>[<https://github.com/EvolEcolGroup/pastclim>]{.smalltext}
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
```{.r}
B <- MAP < 10 * Pthresh
BW <- B & MAP < 5 * Pthresh
BWh <- BW & MAT >= 18
BWk <- BW & MAT < 18
BS <- B & MAP >= 5 * Pthresh
BSh <- BS & MAT >= 18
BSk <- BS & MAT < 18

A <- Thot >= 18 & !B
Af <- A & Pdry >= 60
Am <- A & !Af & Pdry >= 100 - MAP / 25
Aw <- A & !Af & Pdry < 100 - MAP / 25
```
<small>![pastclim::koeppen_geiger()](https://github.com/EvolEcolGroup/pastclim/blob/master/R/koeppen_geiger.R)</small>
:::

:::

:::

[^1]: Beyer, R. M., Krapp, M., & Manica, A. (2020). High-resolution terrestrial climate, bioclimate and vegetation for the last 120,000 years. *Scientific data*, 7(1), 236.


::: notes
- *pastclim* R package to recreate the Koppen Climate classification (KCC) for past periods, currently from 8,000 BC to 5,000 cal BC (expressed here in cal BP)
- KCC based on average temperature and precipitation patterns, dividing them into five main types: tropical, dry, temperate, continental, and polar. Each type is further subdivided based on seasonal precipitation and temperature patterns (30 classes).
- The pastclim KCC current resolution is 30" = 0.5 degrees = c. 50 km. It uses the Beyer *et al.* 2020 dataset.
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}

<p><small>

* In Greece, Thessaly and Macedonia, dense settlements in <span style="color:#FFDC64;">BSk</span> climates (<span style="color:#FFDC64;">Sesklo, Paliambela, Anzabegovo</span>, etc. )
* First Neolithic in Northern Aegean (Ugurlu, idf <b>44</b>) related to first Neolithic in Northwestern Anatolia: <span style="color:#FFFF00;">Barcin</span> (idf <b>9</b>), <span style="color:#FFFF00;">Aktopraklik</span> (idf <b>2</b>)
* The Neolithic pioneer front seems to slow down in Western Greece (ridge line, river basins), exception: <span style="color:#FFFF00;">Sidari</span> (idf <b>42</b>) and Northern Greece.
* New climate: <span style="color:#C8FF50;">Cfa</span> (*Temperate, no dry season, hot summer*). Sites: Mavropigi (idf <b>19</b>), Lefkopetra (idf <b>28</b>), Ofeas (idf <b>32</b>)




</small></p>

:::


::: {.column width="50%"}

<p><small>

* Rapid expansion in the Southern Balkans (<span style="color:#FFFF00;">Csa</span> and <span style="color:#FFDC64;">BSk</span> ).
* Northern Balkans expansion required adapting agriculture and stockbreeding systems to colder climates (<span style="color:#00FFFF;">Dfa</span>, <span style="color:#37C8FF;">Dfb</span>)
* Slowdown of Neolithic expansion. Early northern occupations, such as <span style="color:#37C8FF;">Porodin</span> (idf <b>26</b>).
* South of Italy (off the map) is reached, probably from Corfu: <span style="color:#FFFF00;">Sidari</span> (idf <b>40</b>)
* Confirms: Krauß et al. 2018[^81], Ivanova et al. 2018[^82].

</small></p>

:::

:::

:::

[^81]: Krauß, R., Marinova, E., De Brue, H., & Weninger, B. (2018). The rapid spread of early farming from the Aegean into the Balkans via the Sub-Mediterranean-Aegean Vegetation Zone. Quaternary International, 496, 24-41. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.quaint.2017.01.019
[^82]: Ivanova, M., De Cupere, B., Ethier, J., & Marinova, E. (2018). Pioneer farming in southeast Europe during the early sixth millennium BC: Climate-related adaptations in the exploitation of plants and animals. PLoS One, 13(5), e0197225. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0197225

## Climates evolution

::: columns

::: {.column width="65%"}
![](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/zoometh/neonet/master/doc/talks/2024-simep/img/kcc_meso_neo_1.png){width="850" style="horizontal-align: middle;"}
:::


::: {.column width="35%"}
![](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/zoometh/neonet/master/doc/talks/2024-simep/img/kcc_meso_neo_legend.png){width="350" style="horizontal-align: middle;"}
:::

:::



::: notes
- Late foragers: Drop of the inhabited cold climates from 11k BP to 7k BP. In 9k BP newly occupied occupied Cold, dry summer, cold summer, possibly corresponding to the higher mountain range (Atlas, Alps, Pyrenees, etc.)
- Early Farmers: 11k and 10k 2 main climates, continuous area: Fertile Crescent. Arid climates increases in 9k: arid margins (oasis). 8k and 7k: neolithisation of cold and temperated areas (Bulgaria, Southern Germany, etc.)
- Comparison: LM occupied a larger diversity of ecozones. EF replace HG in cold climate over 4,000 years  
:::
